lessons.title: Your First Budget – Building a Strong Foundation

sections.text: Your budget isn’t just a spreadsheet — it’s your personal roadmap to financial control.
A budget is a plan for allocating income across needs, wants, and future you (savings/investing). It replaces guesswork with clarity.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Without a plan, money leaks into low‑value spending. A budget makes trade‑offs explicit, reduces stress, and accelerates goals.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• List net monthly income and fixed costs (rent/mortgage, utilities, phone, transit, insurance).
• Choose a simple rule to start (e.g., 50/30/20) then adjust to your reality.
• Set a minimum monthly savings target and automate it on payday.
• Track variable spend weekly; course‑correct at your mid‑month review.
• Schedule a 20‑minute month‑end retro to adjust next month’s plan.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Sofia in Toronto nets $4,000/mo. Fixed: $2,300. Automation: $600 to savings on payday. She plans $700 for flexible spend and reviews each Sunday.

quiz.q: A budget is a plan that allocates income across essentials, wants, and future goals so you decide where each dollar goes.
The lesson recommends tracking only variable expenses and ignoring fixed bills when starting a budget.

takeaways: Budgets are about priorities, not perfection.
Small, consistent savings compound into options.

lessons.title: Cash‑Flow Mapping – Seeing the Whole Picture

sections.text: When money feels chaotic, the problem is visibility, not character.
Cash‑flow mapping shows what comes in, when it arrives, and where it goes over time.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Timing mismatches cause overdrafts and anxiety even when annual math looks fine.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• List pay dates, benefit dates, and bill due dates on one calendar.
• Group bills by payday; shift due dates where possible.
• Create two ‘guard rails’: a bill‑pay account and a spend account.
• Move money on payday: bills + savings first, spending last.
• Keep a one‑month ‘cash buffer’ target to smooth timing shocks.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Jordan gets paid bi‑weekly. He moves $1,200 to Bills and $300 to Savings each payday. Groceries, gas, and fun come from Spend. Overdrafts vanish.

quiz.q: Does this lesson focus on practical steps for saving?
Does this lesson claim there’s a guaranteed shortcut that removes risk and effort?

lessons.title: The 50/30/20 (and Friends) – Picking a Starter Rule

sections.text: Rules of thumb aren’t laws — they’re training wheels you can tune.
50/30/20 splits net income into 50% needs, 30% wants, 20% saving/investing. Other patterns: 60/20/20; 70/20/10 while paying debt.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: A simple default reduces decision fatigue and gives you a starting benchmark.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Estimate your current split across needs/wants/saving.
• Pick a starter ratio for 90 days; don’t chase perfection.
• Adjust high‑cost categories (housing, car) slowly; trim wants weekly.
• Increase savings by 1–2% every quarter (‘pay yourself more’).
• Re‑baseline after big life events (move, new job, child).

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Ava starts near 65/25/10. She trims subscriptions and renegotiates internet. After 3 months she’s at 55/25/20 without feeling deprived.

quiz.q: 50/30/20 is a starting point that you can tune over time; it is not a law you must follow exactly.
The lesson says to change ratios weekly based on headlines and to chase perfection each month.

lessons.title: Expense Triage – Cutting Without Feeling Deprived

sections.text: Cutting everything fails. Cutting the right things works.
Expense triage prioritizes high‑cost/low‑joy items first and preserves high‑joy/low‑cost items.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: You keep motivation when cuts don’t feel like punishment.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Make a Joy vs. Cost matrix for the last 90 days of spending.
• Cancel or downgrade high‑cost/low‑joy items first.
• Negotiate recurring bills (phone, internet, insurance).
• Batch ‘fun’ spending into planned sessions you can look forward to.
• Re‑route savings from cuts into your automation immediately.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Chris cut two unused subscriptions ($46/mo) and switched to a cheaper phone plan ($25 saved). He kept weekly coffee with a friend. Net save: $71/mo.

quiz.q: You should first target high‑cost, low‑joy expenses and preserve low‑cost, high‑joy items.
The fastest way to save is to cut your favorite low‑cost treats before touching unused subscriptions or overpriced plans.

takeaways: Automate the savings you free up.

lessons.title: Emergency Funds – Building Your Personal Shock Absorber

sections.text: An emergency fund turns a crisis into an inconvenience.
A cash reserve for true emergencies: job loss, medical, urgent repairs. Separate from investing.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: It prevents high‑interest debt and buys decision time when life hits.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Set stages: Starter ($1,000), Stable (1–3 months), Secure (3–6+ months).
• Automate contributions into a separate high‑interest savings account.
• Define ‘emergency’ in writing to avoid misuse.
• Rebuild immediately after you use it.
• Keep it easy to access but not too easy to spend.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Priya saved a $1,000 starter fund in 4 months. A flat tire cost $320 — paid from the fund, no credit card debt, then rebuilt in two pay cycles.

quiz.q: A sensible first milestone for an emergency fund is around $1,000 before building toward 1–3 months of expenses.
It’s best to invest your emergency fund for higher returns since you rarely need to access it quickly.

lessons.title: Automation – Let Systems Do the Heavy Lifting

sections.text: If it has to rely on willpower, it probably won’t last.
Automation moves money on a schedule: savings, bill‑pay, and debt payments happen without you.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: It removes decision fatigue and makes the ‘right’ thing the default.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Set savings transfers for payday (before spending begins).
• Enable automatic bill payments with reminders for visibility.
• Use round‑ups or rules to sweep spare change to savings.
• Auto‑increase savings 1% every quarter (‘raise for future you’).
• Review automations quarterly for drift.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Diego set $250/pay to savings and auto‑paid utilities. Within 6 months he had $3,000 saved without feeling restricted day‑to‑day.

quiz.q: Scheduling savings to move on payday helps you save before lifestyle spending ramps up.
Manual transfers are preferred because automation makes it too easy to save and you might forget to review later.

lessons.title: Sinking Funds – Plan for the Predictable ‘Surprises’

sections.text: Christmas isn’t an emergency. Neither is car maintenance.
Sinking funds are mini‑buckets for non‑monthly costs you know are coming.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: They prevent recurring ‘surprise’ expenses from wrecking your month.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• List irregular expenses (car, travel, gifts, school, annual fees).
• Divide each annual cost by 12 and save monthly into labeled buckets.
• Use a single savings account with sub‑labels or multiple accounts.
• Spend only from the matching bucket.
• Review categories annually and rebalance.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Nia budgets $900/yr for car maintenance → $75/mo into ‘Car’ fund. When brakes cost $420, the money is ready — no panic.

quiz.q: Sinking funds break non‑monthly costs (like car maintenance or gifts) into monthly contributions, often by dividing the annual amount by 12.
Holidays and maintenance are emergencies, so the lesson recommends using your emergency fund for them instead of planning ahead.

lessons.title: Groceries, Dining, and the ‘Flex’ Categories

sections.text: The easiest overspending happens where tracking is fuzzier.
Flex categories vary weekly (groceries, dining, rideshare). Guardrails prevent drift.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Simple constraints beat perfect tracking in high‑variance categories.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Set a weekly grocery envelope and shop with a list.
• Batch cook once per week; pre‑portion snacks to cut impulse buys.
• Plan dining out intentionally (e.g., one nice meal per week).
• Use a separate card/wallet for flex spend to increase awareness.
• If you overshoot one week, undershoot the next.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Malik set $120/wk for groceries and $40 for dining. A separate debit card helped him notice patterns and stay on target by week 3.

quiz.q: Weekly limits and a separate card or wallet for ‘flex’ spending make it easier to stay on target.
The lesson suggests skipping grocery lists to stay flexible and trusting that monthly totals will work out.

takeaways: Fewer decisions at the store = lower spend.

lessons.title: Big Rocks – Housing, Transportation, and Insurance

sections.text: Tiny cuts can’t fix an oversized anchor expense.
‘Big rocks’ are large, recurring costs that dominate budgets. Optimizing them creates outsized savings.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Shaving 10–20% off a major category frees more than canceling every latte.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Benchmark housing and car total % of take‑home pay.
• Consider housemates, downsizing, or refinancing when numbers are tight.
• Use TCO (total cost of ownership) for cars, not just payments.
• Shop insurance annually; increase deductibles if appropriate.
• Apply half of any savings to goals immediately to lock them in.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Leah switched to transit + car‑share, cutting monthly transport from $620 to $280. She rerouted $170/mo into savings and $170/mo to debt prepayments.

quiz.q: Optimizing large recurring costs (housing, transportation, insurance) creates bigger, more durable savings than tiny cuts.
Canceling coffee and small treats is the primary way to fix an oversized housing or car budget.

takeaways: Focus energy where dollars are biggest.
Lock in savings or lifestyle creep eats them.

lessons.title: Monthly Retros – Iterate Like a Product Team

sections.text: Your budget isn’t a contract; it’s a draft that learns.
A monthly retro reviews what worked, what didn’t, and what to try next.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Iteration beats perfection — small tweaks monthly lead to compounding improvements.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Schedule a 20‑minute calendar block at month‑end.
• Check category drift and note one root cause.
• Decide one experiment to try next month.
• Increase automation if the experiment works.
• Write a one‑line ‘money rule’ for the month and pin it.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: After noticing weekend overspending, Theo planned Sunday meal prep and moved dining money to a pre‑paid card. Next month came in on target.

quiz.q: A monthly retro identifies one root cause of drift and one experiment to try next month.
The goal of a monthly retro is to punish overspending and overhaul the entire system at once.

takeaways: One change at a time beats overhaul.

lessons.title: Credit Scores Demystified

sections.text: Your credit score is a trust signal — not your worth.
A credit score summarizes how reliably you’ve handled credit. Key factors: payment history, utilization, age of accounts, mix, inquiries.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Knowing the levers lets you protect your access to low‑cost borrowing when you truly need it.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Pay on time — set autopay for at least minimums.
• Keep utilization under ~30% (under 10% is excellent).
• Avoid closing your oldest card (it affects age).
• Limit hard inquiries; batch applications.
• Check reports annually and dispute errors.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Rae keeps card balances under 10% and autopays minimums. A missed bill never tanks her score again.

quiz.q: On‑time payment history and low utilization are two of the most important factors in your credit score.
Closing your oldest card and applying for multiple new accounts usually improves your score quickly.

takeaways: Old accounts help your average age.

lessons.title: Good Debt vs. Bad Debt

sections.text: Not all debt is equal — cost and purpose matter.
‘Good’ debt funds assets that appreciate or improve earning power (e.g., education, reasonable mortgage). ‘Bad’ debt is high‑interest consumer debt.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Clarity prevents shame spirals and focuses your payoff strategy where it counts.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• List all debts with balances, rates, and purpose.
• Label by cost and usefulness (asset‑building vs. consumption).
• Prioritize high‑interest consumer debt for accelerated payoff.
• Keep low‑rate, productive debt manageable and on autopay.
• Avoid new consumer debt while paying down.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Mina has a 2.2% car loan and 22% credit card debt. She keeps the car loan on autopay and aggressively attacks the card balance.

quiz.q: High‑interest consumer debt is typically the first payoff priority compared to low‑rate, productive debt.
A low‑rate mortgage and a 22% store card should be treated the same when choosing what to pay down first.

takeaways: Autopay the rest to avoid backsliding.

lessons.title: Debt Inventory – Know the Enemy

sections.text: You can’t beat what you don’t measure.
A full inventory lists every debt: balance, APR, minimum, due date, lender, and status.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Seeing the total picture reveals quick wins and risk hotspots.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Create a single list or spreadsheet of all debts.
• Sort by APR descending to see most expensive first.
• Note any fees, penalties, or promotional periods.
• Call lenders to confirm details and options.
• Set autopay for minimums immediately.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: After building an inventory, Omar found a 27% store card he’d forgotten. Closing that loop saved him $40/mo in interest.

quiz.q: Listing every debt with balance and APR reveals the most expensive accounts to target first.
You can skip small store cards in your inventory because they don’t affect your payoff plan much.

takeaways: APR sort shows where dollars matter.

lessons.title: Avalanche vs. Snowball – Picking Your Payoff Strategy

sections.text: The best plan is the one you’ll stick to.
Avalanche = highest APR first (mathematically optimal). Snowball = smallest balance first (motivational wins).

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Matching strategy to your psychology increases the odds you finish.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Calculate your monthly ‘extra’ payoff amount.
• Choose avalanche for lowest total interest; snowball for momentum.
• Automate extra payments to the target account.
• Roll freed‑up minimums into the next debt (‘debt snowballing’).
• Celebrate milestones to keep energy high.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Kayla chose snowball to see quick wins. Three small balances disappeared in 5 months, building momentum for bigger ones.

quiz.q: Avalanche minimizes total interest by targeting the highest APR first, while snowball builds momentum by paying the smallest balance first.
Switching strategies every week is recommended so you don’t get bored with your plan.

takeaways: Either method works if you persist.
Motivation is a feature, not a flaw.

lessons.title: Negotiating with Lenders

sections.text: You’re not stuck with the status quo — ask.
Lenders may reduce rates, waive fees, or set hardship plans if you call early and propose a concrete plan.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: A lower APR or fee relief can meaningfully speed up payoff.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Prepare: income, expenses, and a proposed payment you can keep.
• Ask for rate reductions, fee waivers, and due‑date changes.
• Request hardship programs if needed — temporary but helpful.
• Get everything in writing and calendar a follow‑up check.
• If denied, set a reminder and try again in 90 days.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: After a calm call, Jin cut one card’s APR from 23.9% to 17.9%, saving ~$30/mo, which he rerouted to principal.

quiz.q: Calling early with a concrete proposal can lead to lower APRs or waived fees.
It’s best to wait until you miss several payments before contacting lenders about options.

lessons.title: Balance Transfers & Consolidation – Use with Caution

sections.text: 0% isn’t free if it causes backsliding.
Balance transfers or consolidation loans can lower interest temporarily, but risks include fees and re‑accumulating debt.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Tools are helpful only with behavior change and a firm payoff plan.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Compare fees vs. savings; calculate your breakeven.
• Pay within the promo period; set autopay to finish a month early.
• Do not spend on the old card after transferring.
• Avoid extending terms that keep you in debt longer.
• Pair with a strict budget and spending freeze.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Sam transferred $4,000 to 0% for 12 months with a 3% fee. He set $350/mo autopay to finish in 12 months and cut the old card.

quiz.q: After a transfer, set autopay to finish within the promo period and avoid spending on the old card.
Once you transfer a balance, it’s fine to use the old card again because the debt moved elsewhere.

lessons.title: Protecting Your Credit While Paying Off Debt

sections.text: You can reduce debt without wrecking your score.
On‑time minimums, low utilization, and stable accounts maintain your profile during payoff.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Protecting your access to fair rates saves money later.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Autopay minimums to protect payment history.
• Keep utilization low; consider an extra mid‑cycle payment.
• Avoid closing old accounts during payoff.
• Space out applications until after debt is reduced.
• Monitor reports for errors quarterly.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Arun paid a mid‑cycle $200 to drop utilization before a mortgage application. It nudged his score higher at the right time.

quiz.q: Autopaying at least the minimums and keeping utilization low protect your score during payoff.
Closing your oldest accounts during payoff is a good idea because it simplifies your wallet and boosts your score.

takeaways: Payment history and utilization are key.
Avoid avoidable dings while in payoff mode.

lessons.title: Debt Freedom Plan – Your Written Strategy

sections.text: A plan you can see beats a plan in your head.
A one‑page plan defines your method, monthly extra, target order, milestones, and safeguards.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Clear rules prevent emotion‑based backtracking.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Write your method (avalanche or snowball) and why.
• Fix your monthly extra amount and due date.
• List the order of debts and expected payoff dates.
• Define relapse guards (spending freeze rules, automation).
• Schedule monthly check‑ins and milestone rewards.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Nora printed her plan and taped it inside a cabinet. Checking off balances became a ritual that kept her going.

quiz.q: A one‑page plan includes your method, a fixed extra payment you can sustain, the payoff order, and relapse guards.
It’s better to keep your plan in your head so you can change it whenever your mood shifts.

lessons.title: Emergency Protocols – When Life Happens During Payoff

sections.text: Progress isn’t linear — plan for bumps.
A protocol defines what to do if income drops or costs spike so you avoid high‑interest debt.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Pre‑made decisions keep you calm under stress.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• List the order to cut discretionary categories.
• Pause extra payoff temporarily, not minimums.
• Activate side income or sell unused items.
• Call lenders early to request hardship options.
• Rebuild your buffer first, then resume payoff.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: After a car repair, Eli paused extra payments for one month, used his buffer, then resumed. The plan survived intact.

quiz.q: In a setback, pause extra payments but keep minimums on time, then rebuild your buffer and resume the plan.
When an unexpected bill hits, stop paying all debts for a while to reduce stress and restart later.

lessons.title: Life After Debt – Staying Out

sections.text: Getting out is step one. Staying out is the mission.
Post‑debt habits (automation, sinking funds, intentional spending) prevent relapse.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Use freed‑up cash for wealth building instead of lifestyle creep.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Keep your payoff autopay slot and redirect it to savings/investing.
• Maintain sinking funds for irregular costs.
• Do a quarterly subscription/bill audit.
• Use a cooling‑off rule for new big purchases (e.g., 48 hours).
• Write a post‑debt vision: what you’re saying yes to now.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: When Maya finished paying $400/mo on debt, she redirected it to an investment account. A year later she had nearly $5,000 invested.

quiz.q: Redirecting the old debt payment into savings or investing helps prevent lifestyle creep and builds wealth.
After becoming debt‑free, you should spend the former payment right away because you’ve earned it.

takeaways: Behavior change locks in the win.
Invest the payment you no longer need.

lessons.title: Why Invest? The Cost of Waiting

sections.text: Time in the market beats timing the market.
Investing puts money to work to outpace inflation and grow via compounding.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Delaying even a few years noticeably shrinks long‑term outcomes.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Set a purpose: retirement, home, education, freedom.
• Decide a starter monthly amount you can stick with.
• Automate contributions to a diversified fund.
• Keep a separate emergency fund (don’t invest that money).
• Commit to a 10‑year horizon for long‑term goals.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: If Alex invests $300/mo starting at 25 with 6% returns, by 45 they may have ~\$139k vs. ~\$83k starting at 30 (illustrative).

quiz.q: Starting earlier gives compounding more time to work, which can meaningfully increase long‑term results.
Waiting a few years doesn’t matter much because compounding only helps at the end.

lessons.title: Risk & Reward – Volatility Explained

sections.text: Short‑term dips are the price of long‑term growth.
Higher expected returns usually come with higher volatility (price swings).

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Understanding risk prevents panic selling at the worst times.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Match risk to your time horizon and temperament.
• Expect temporary drops; plan for them.
• Diversify so no single asset dominates results.
• Use broad index funds to capture the market.
• Check accounts quarterly, not daily.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Jamie saw a 15% drop one year but stayed invested. The following year recovered, and the plan stayed on track.

quiz.q: Short‑term volatility is normal; a diversified, long‑term plan helps you avoid panic selling.
The lesson recommends checking prices constantly and selling at the first sign of a drop.

lessons.title: Accounts 101 – Tax‑Advantaged First

sections.text: The account wrapper can boost your outcome without changing your investments.
Tax‑advantaged accounts (like RRSP/TFSA equivalents) shelter growth or contributions depending on the rules.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Choosing the right account order can add years of progress with the same savings.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• List your available account types and limits.
• Use tax‑advantaged accounts before taxable (if eligible).
• Keep emergency cash outside investment accounts.
• Avoid frequent withdrawals that reset room or cause penalties.
• Document your order of contributions each year.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Taylor contributes monthly to a tax‑advantaged account first, then a taxable account once room is used. Same savings, better after‑tax outcome.

quiz.q: Does this lesson focus on practical steps for investing?
Does this lesson claim there’s a guaranteed shortcut that removes risk and effort?

lessons.title: Asset Allocation – The Big Decision

sections.text: Your mix of stocks and bonds drives most of your experience.
Allocation sets expected risk/return. More stocks = higher growth and swings; more bonds = stability but lower returns.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Picking a sensible mix and staying the course beats chasing performance.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Choose a diversified stock/bond mix (e.g., 80/20, 60/40) based on horizon.
• Use low‑cost index funds or a single balanced/‘all‑in‑one’ ETF.
• Write a simple policy: your target mix and when to rebalance.
• Avoid tinkering based on headlines.
• Revisit allocation as life stage changes.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: A 60/40 investor slept better during downturns and still reached goals on schedule.

quiz.q: Your stock/bond mix largely determines your portfolio’s risk and return over time.
Choosing individual hot stocks matters more than your overall asset allocation.

takeaways: Low cost and diversification are core.
Document your policy to reduce impulse moves.

lessons.title: Fees – Small Percentages, Big Impact

sections.text: You don’t control markets, but you do control costs.
Higher fees compound against you; low‑cost funds keep more of your returns.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: A 1% fee gap over decades can mean tens of thousands lost.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Know your MER/expense ratios and trading costs.
• Prefer broad, low‑cost index funds.
• Avoid unnecessary turnover and taxes.
• Ask providers for lower‑cost options when available.
• Review fees annually as part of your retrofit.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Switching from 1.2% to 0.2% fees on a $50k portfolio saves ~$500/yr at the start — savings compound as the portfolio grows.

quiz.q: Lower fees mean more of your returns remain invested to compound over time.
A 1% fee difference is trivial and doesn’t affect long‑term outcomes.

lessons.title: Diversification – Don’t Bet the Farm

sections.text: Single‑stock risk is avoidable risk.
Diversification spreads exposure across many companies and regions.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: It reduces the impact of any one failure and increases the odds of average market returns.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Use total‑market index funds instead of picking winners.
• Add global exposure rather than home‑country bias only.
• Avoid concentrated bets in your employer’s stock.
• Rebalance annually to target weights.
• Stay consistent across accounts.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Instead of three tech names, Zoe bought a total‑market fund. When one sector lagged, others carried the load.

quiz.q: Broad diversification reduces the impact of any single company or sector underperforming.
Concentrating in a few favorite stocks is safer because you can monitor them closely.

lessons.title: Behavioral Pitfalls – Your Brain on Money

sections.text: The enemy is often in the mirror, not the market.
Common pitfalls: chasing performance, loss aversion, overconfidence, and recency bias.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Naming biases helps you design guardrails that protect your plan.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Write ‘if‑then’ rules (e.g., if market drops 15%, then rebalance; don’t sell).
• Automate contributions so feelings don’t drive timing.
• Use a portfolio ‘policy’ document to guide future you.
• Check accounts on a schedule (e.g., quarterly).
• Discuss big moves with a trusted partner before acting.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: When markets dipped, Ken followed his pre‑written rule to rebalance instead of panic‑selling. The recovery rewarded patience.

quiz.q: A written investment policy and scheduled check‑ins help counter emotional decisions.
Following hot tips and switching strategies monthly is a good way to avoid bias.

lessons.title: Rebalancing – Tidying Your Portfolio

sections.text: Markets move; your target mix drifts.
Rebalancing nudges holdings back to target weights, selling a bit of what grew and buying what lagged.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: It enforces buy‑low/sell‑high behavior mechanically.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Pick a schedule (annual/semiannual) or bands (e.g., ±5%).
• Use new contributions to reduce trading where possible.
• Mind taxes when rebalancing in taxable accounts.
• Document your trigger to avoid guesswork.
• Stick to the rule during both booms and dips.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: A 70/30 portfolio drifted to 78/22. Alex rebalanced back to target using new contributions plus a small trade.

quiz.q: Rebalancing nudges holdings back to target weights and enforces buy‑low/sell‑high behavior.
You should only add to the most recent winners and ignore target weights to maximize momentum.

takeaways: Tax awareness matters in taxable accounts.

lessons.title: Dollar‑Cost Averaging & Lump Sums

sections.text: Consistency beats perfection in timing.
Dollar‑cost averaging (DCA) invests a fixed amount on a schedule; lump sum invests all at once. Historically, lump sum often wins, but DCA helps behavior.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: The best choice is the one that keeps you invested and calm.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• For windfalls, choose lump sum if you can stomach volatility; otherwise DCA over a set period.
• Automate recurring contributions monthly or per‑paycheque.
• Avoid pausing DCA due to headlines.
• Pair with your rebalancing rule.
• Document your choice to avoid second‑guessing.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: When Pat received a bonus, they invested 60% immediately and DCA’d the rest over 4 months to sleep better.

quiz.q: Does this lesson focus on practical steps for investing?
Does this lesson claim there’s a guaranteed shortcut that removes risk and effort?

lessons.title: Getting Started – Your First Portfolio

sections.text: Simple beats fancy — especially at the start.
A low‑cost, diversified fund or all‑in‑one portfolio removes complexity and decision fatigue.

sections.label: Why it matters
sections.text: Starting now with a simple setup beats waiting to design the ‘perfect’ portfolio.

sections.label: How to apply
sections.text:
• Pick a risk‑appropriate all‑in‑one fund or a simple 2‑fund mix (broad stock + bonds).
• Automate contributions each payday.
• Write a one‑page policy: allocation, rebalancing, and behavior rules.
• Set quarterly calendar reminders to review.
• Ignore noise; focus on your savings rate.

sections.label: Example
sections.text: Chris chose a balanced all‑in‑one fund, set $250/pay contributions, and wrote a one‑page policy. He’s finally in motion.

quiz.q: A low‑cost, diversified all‑in‑one fund is a simple way to start and reduce decision fatigue.
It’s best to wait for the perfect portfolio design before investing your first dollar.

takeaways: Savings rate matters most early on.
